title: J&J's single-dose coronavirus vaccine is 66% effective against COVID-19, raising worries that some variants may lower protection
text: The US effort to halt the coronavirus got some good news on Friday as another vaccine succeeded in the final stages of clinical research. The single-dose vaccine, developed by healthcare giant Johnson & Johnson with US government funding, proved to be 66% effective at preventing people from catching COVID-19, J&J said in a statement. That's significantly lower than the protection offered by shots from Pfizer and from Moderna, though both of those shots require two doses.

The vaccine candidate was 72% effective in the U.S. trial, the company said in a statement.

text: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee is now scheduled to meet Feb. 26 for an all-day meeting to discuss Johnson & Johnson's COVID-19 vaccine candidate. This is the next step in the regulatory process after J&J said Thursday it has submitted an application for its experimental vaccine to the FDA.

title: Johnson & Johnson submits one-shot coronavirus vaccine for US approval
text: Johnson & Johnson  Inc (NYSE:JNJ) said last night it has filed for emergency use authorisation of its one-dose Coronavirus (COVID-19) vaccine with US regulator, the Food & Drug Administration (FDA). The application follows the publication of trial data last month that showed the drug was 66% effective in preventing infections, though the figure was higher at 72% among US participants.

title: Why Johnson & Johnson's Vaccine Data Is Actually Great News

title: Janssen's Erleada Plus, Zytiga Plus Prednisone Combo Treatment Shows Clinical Benefit In Late-Stage Prostate Cancer Study
text: Johnson & Johnson's (NYSE: JNJ) unit Janssen Pharmaceutical has announced results from Phase 3 ACIS study, evaluating the efficacy and safety of Erleada (apalutamide) and Zytiga (abiraterone) plus prednisone (treatment arm) compared to placebo and Zytiga plus prednisone (control arm) in prostate cancer patients with chemotherapy-naïve disease who received androgen deprivation therapy. JNJ will present the results at the American Society of Clinical Oncology's Genitourinary Cancers Symposium.

title: J&J CEO says people may need annual Covid vaccine shots for the next several years
Key Words: Expect to get COVID-19 shots for years to come, Johnson & Johnson CEO says
text: In an interview with CNBC, CEO Alex Gorsky said mutations of the coronavirus will necessitate changes to vaccines, much like annual flu shots.
